abide by.meaning: To respect or obey a decision, a law or a rule
abide by.example: If you want to keep your job here, you must abide by our rules.

account for.example: I hope you can account for the time you were out!

add up.example: The facts in the case just don’t add up.

advise against.example: I advise against walking alone in this neighborhood.

agree with.meaning: To have the same opinion as someone else.
agree with.example: I agree with you. I think you should go as well.

allow for.example: We need to allow for unexpected charges along the way.

appeal to.meaning: To plead or make a request To be attractive or interesting
appeal to.example: He appealed to the court to change its decision. A vacation of sunbathing doesn’t appeal to me.

apply for.meaning: To make a formal request for something (job, permit, loan etc.)
apply for.example: He applied for a scholarship for next semester.

back away.meaning: To move backwards, in fear or dislike
back away.example: When he saw the bear, he backed away in fright.

back down.example: Local authorities backed down on their threats to build on that part of the beach.

back up.meaning: To give support or encouragement To make a copy of (file, program, etc.)
back up.example: I’m going to be very strict with him. I hope you’ll back me up on this? You should back up all your computer files in a secure location.

bank on.meaning: To base your hopes on something / someone
bank on.example: I’m banking on you to help with the charity event.

black out.example: Jenna fell in the parking lot and blacked out.

block off.example: The police blocked off the street after the explosion.

blow up.example: Tommy blew up the red balloon. Don’t blow up at me. It’s not my fault.

boil down to.example: It all boils down to who has more power.

boot up.meaning: To start a computer by loading an operating system or program
boot up.example: You need to boot up your computer before you begin to work.

break away.example: One of the wolves broke away from his pack.

break down.meaning: To go out of order, cease to function To lose control of one’s emotions
break down.example: The washing machine broke down so we had to call in the repair technician. John broke down when he heard the news.

break into.example: Burglars broke into my car last night.

break out.example: Rioting broke out after the government raised the fuel prices again.

break out of.meaning: To escape from a place by force
break out of.example: Several prisoners broke out of jail.

break up.meaning: To come to an end (marriage, relationship)
break up.example: She broke up with Daniel after dating him for five years.

bring up.example: Sara is bringing up her children by herself.

brush up on.meaning: To improve, refresh one’s knowledge of something
brush up on.example: I must brush up on my French before going to Paris next month.

bump into.meaning: To meet by chance or unexpectedly
bump into.example: I bumped into Adam at the bank. He says “hello”.

burn out.meaning: stop (something) working become exhausted from over-working
burn out.example: The light bulb burnt out. Please change it. She needs to work fewer hours. Otherwise she will burn out.

call back.example: Could please call back in ten minutes?

call off.example: The game was called off because of bad weather.

calm down.meaning: To become more relaxed, less angry or upset
calm down.example: It took Kylie several hours to calm down after she saw the accident.

carry on.example: The soldiers carried on walking in order to get to their post before dark.

carry out.meaning: To do something as specified (a plan, an order, a threat) To perform or conduct (test, experiment)
carry out.example: His orders were carried out to the letter. That company does not carry out tests on animals.

check in.meaning: To register at a hotel or airport
check in.example: They said I must check in at least three hours before my flight.

check out.meaning: To pay one’s bill and leave (a hotel) To investigate
check out.example: Donna checked out of the hotel this morning. I don’t know if this price is correct. I’ll check it out online.

clam up.example: When the police started asking questions, the suspect clammed up.

clamp down on.meaning: To act strictly to prevent something
clamp down on.example: The local authorities have decided to clamp down on illegal parking in handicapped parking places.

clear out.meaning: To act strictly to prevent something
clear out.example: The local authorities have decided to clamp down on illegal parking in handicapped parking places.

come across.meaning: To find by chance To appear, seem, make an impression
come across.example: I was cleaning up and came across some old photos of you. The politician came across as a complete fool during the TV interview.

come forward.example: Has the owner of the winning lotto ticket come forward?

count on.meaning: To rely or depend on (for help)
count on.example: You can count on me to keep your secret.

cut down on.meaning: To reduce in number or size
cut down on.example: I’ve decided to cut down on the amount of sweets I eat.

cut out.meaning: To remove using scissors To stop doing something
cut out.example: She cut out a coupon from the newspaper. You need to cut out all red meat from your diet.

deal with.meaning: To handle, take care of (problem, situation)
deal with.example: Catherine is not good at dealing with stress.

die down.meaning: To calm down, become less strong
die down.example: After the storm died down, we went outside to see the damage it had caused.

do without.example: She didn’t get a salary this month, so she’ll have to do without extra treats.

drag on.example: The suspect’s trial dragged on longer than we had expected!

draw up.example: They drew up a contract and had me sign it.

dress up.example: Their wedding gave us a chance to dress up and get out of the house.

drop in.meaning: To visit, usually on the way somewhere
drop in.example: Why don’t you drop in to see us on your way home?

drop off.meaning: To deliver someone or something To fall asleep
drop off.example: I’ll drop off the papers later today. I often drop off in front of the TV.

drop out.example: Zack dropped out of college and joined the army.

ease off.meaning: To reduce, become less severe or slow down (pain, traffic, work)

end in.meaning: To finish in a certain way; result in

end up.meaning: To finally reach a state, place or action
end up.example: If you don’t improve your work habits, you’ll end up being fired.

fall through.example: His plans to trek through South America fell through when he got sick.

figure out.example: He’s trying to figure out how to earn enough money to go on the trip to Spain.

fill out.example: Please fill out the enclosed form and return it as soon as possible.

find out.example: I’m going to to find out who’s responsible for the power cut.

focus on.example: Tom had difficultty focusing on work the day before his holiday started.

get along (with).meaning: To be on good terms; work well with
get along (with).example: It’s important to get along with your team supervisor.

get at.example: What are you getting at? Do you think I’m to blame?

get away.example: I think we should get away for the weekend.

get by.meaning: To manage to cope or to survive
get by.example: Students without jobs have a hard time getting by.

get in.example: When did you get in last night?

get into (+noun).example: How did you get into your car without the keys?

get off.meaning: To leave (bus, train, plane) To remove
get off.example: You should get off the train in Kings Heath. I can’t get the ink stain off my shirt.

get on.example: I’m trying to get on the flight to Brussels.

get on with (something).meaning: To continue to do; make progress
get on with (something).example: After they split up, she had a hard time getting on with her life.

get on (well) with (somebody).meaning: To have a good relationship with
get on (well) with (somebody).example: He doesnt get on very well with the other members of the committee.

get out.example: He had a hard time getting out of Newark because of the snow?

get out of.example: Edna’s trying to get out of working the night shift.

get over.example: Mary had the chickenpox last week but she got over it.

get rid of.example: Please get rid of that old t-shirt. It’s so ragged.

get together.example: Let’s get together for your birthday on Saturday.

get up.example: Will you please get up? You’ve got a class in 20 minutes.

give in.meaning: To cease opposition; yield To To hand in; submit
give in.example: We will never give in to the terrorists’ demands. I’ll give in my paper tomorrow.

give up.example: Morris gave up drinking 10 years ago.

go through.example: Andy went through a lot of pain after his mother died.

grow up.meaning: To spend one’s childhood; develop; become an adult
grow up.example: He’s like Peter Pan. He never really grew up at all.

hand in.example: Please hand in your papers before Friday.

hand out.example: Susan volunteered at the shelter where she handed out warm clothes.

hang out.meaning: To spend time in a particular place or with a group of friends
hang out.example: Which pub does the team hang out at after the game?

hang up.example: If you hang up now, I’ll never speak to you again.

hold on.example: Please hold on and a representative will answer your call. She was so scared on the rollercoaster ride that she held on for dear life.

hurry up.example: Hurry up and finish your lunch or we’ll miss the train.

iron out.meaning: To resolve by discussion, eliminate differences
iron out.example: The two countries met at the conference to iron out their differences.

join in.example: Yes David, you can join in the discussion any time you like.

join up.meaning: To engage in, become a member of To meet and unite with
join up.example: There was a war on, so some kids were only sixteen when they joined up. Let’s separate now and join up later at the restaurant.

keep on.example: If you keep on making that noise I will get annoyed.

keep up with.meaning: To stay at the same level as someone or something
keep up with.example: I read the paper every day to keep up with the news.

kick off.example: The rugby match kicked off at 3 o’clock.

leave out.example: Please check your form again and make sure nothing is left out.

let down.example: I feel so let down because they promised me a puppy but all I got was a doll.

look after.example: Andy can you look after your sister until I get back?

look down on.example: She’s such a snob. She always looks down on anyone who is poor.

look on.meaning: To be a spectator at an event
look on.example: If you don’t want to take part in the game you can look on for now.

look for.example: Harry went to the shop to look for a new computer.

look forward to.meaning: To await or anticipate with pleasure
look forward to.example: I’m looking forward to my birthday. It’s in two days time.

look up to.example: I always looked up to my father. He was a great man.

make fun of.meaning: To laugh at/ make jokes about
make fun of.example: It’s not nice to make fun of people in wheelchairs.

make up.example: That’s a good excuse. Did you make up it up yourself?

mix up.meaning: To mistake one thing or person for another
mix up.example: She had so many cats that she kept mixing up their names.

move in.meaning: To arrive in a new home or office
move in.example: Did you hear? Our new neighbors are moving in this afternoon.

move out.meaning: To leave your home/office for another one.
move out.example: When are you moving out? We need your office for the new guy.

nod off.example: You were so tired after the game that you nodded off on the couch.

own up.example: Come on. Own up. We know you did it!

pass away.example: Your grandfather passed away peacefully in his sleep last night.

pass out.example: He didn’t drink enough water so he passed out at the end of the race.

pay back.example: I’ll pay you back as soon as I get the loan.

put off.meaning: To postpone, arrange a later date
put off.example: Don’t put off until tomorrow, what you can do today.

put on.example: It’s very dark in here. Please put on the light on.

put out.example: The fire fighters were able to put out fire in ten minutes.

put up.meaning: To accommodate, give somebody a bed
put up.example: I can put you up until the weekend but then I’m going away.

pick up.example: I’ll pick you up at around 7:00 to take you to the airport.

point out.example: As I already pointed out, there was a mistake in your calculation.

rely on.meaning: To count on, depend on, trust
rely on.example: You can rely on me. I always arrive on time.

rule out.example: Since he had a sound alibi, the police ruled him out as a suspect.

run away.meaning: To escape from a place or suddenly leave
run away.example: He ran away from home and joined the circus.

run into.meaning: To meet by accident or unexpectedly (also: bump into)
run into.example: I’m so glad I ran into you. I need to ask you something.

run out of.meaning: To have no more of something.
run out of.example: We’ve run out of milk. I’ll just pop next door to borrow some.

set off.example: Let’s set off early to miss the rush hour traffic.

set up.example: They set up their own company when they were still in high school.

shop around.example: Don’t buy that. Let’s shop around and see if we can find something cheaper.

show off.meaning: To brag or want to be admired
show off.example: He’s such a show off. He has to tell everybody about his new computer.

show up.example: I don’t think she’ll show up tonight. Her daughter is sick.

shut up (impolite).example: Shut up, you’re spoiling the movie!

sit down.example: I think you should sit down. It’s bad news.

stand up.meaning: To rise from a sitting position
stand up.example: The whole stadium stood up for the national anthem.

stick up for.example: My big brother always stuck up for me when I got into a fight.

take after.meaning: To resemble, in appearance or character
take after.example: Angie really takes after her grandmother.

take care of.example: Please take care of my cat when I’m away.

take off.example: The plane will take off as soon as the fog lifts.

take on.example: I hear they’re taking on extra staff for this event.

take out.example: Please take out your mobile phones and turn them off.

talk over.example: Thats something youll need to talk over with your doctor.

tell off.example: The coach told her off for not trying hard enough.

think over.example: Take your time and think it over before you decide.

try on.meaning: To wear something to see if it suits or fits
try on.example: Go ahead, try it on and see if it fits?

turn down.example: I asked her out but she turned me down flat.

use up.meaning: To finish a product (so that there’s none left)
use up.example: Your parents used up all the coffee!

watch out.example: Watch out! There’s a dog in the road.

wear out.meaning: To become unusable To become very tired
wear out.example: Julie wore out her shoes running the marathons. Julie was worn out after all that running.

work out.meaning: To do physical exercise To find a solution or calculate something
work out.example: You should work out twice a week at the gym. Can you work this out? I’m no good at math.

wipe off.example: I’ll wash up if you wipe off the table.
